fullText: Hello friends, we're going to be talking about speci today again. You guessed it. And I wanted to specifically talk about some enhancement but also a workflow type that we have not discussed yet. And that is parallel implementations of the same specification. Uh I mentioned it before, right? Like the the beauty of the fact that we have a specification that is detached from technical details is that we can actually create multiple variations of it to see what it looks like and then we pick the best and we merge it into Maine, our core product. And I wanted to show you this today on an example product that I have built over the weekend that is called Hawaii diff. Hawaii diff is a website that I built that essentially aggregates the camera views from Monaca on the big island of Hawaii. So what happens is that there is a Monaca weather center. It's uh managed by the University of Hawaii at Hilo and what it does is provides a view on a bunch of webcams at the observatory right at the observatories at the top of the mountain. And this is always nice to just kind of browse through and be able to see um the cameras because it's kind of neat. Like I have not been to Hawaii in some time. So being able to just kind of browse the cameras and click around and see what it looks like is nice. But the view here is very inconsistent, right? Like here I landed on this um page. Uh here if I go to another camera view, it's going to go to like another page for uh Noah. So we're going to go back. Right? So there's all these inconsistencies. It's hard to navigate and hard to browse this the way I want to browse this. So to mitigate this, I have built this experience that basically grabs all the images, aggregates them in GitHub. I'll show you in a second.
